D011615 | OPS301 = | OtherCodes = | HCPCSlevel2 = }} 'Group psychotherapy' or
'group therapy' is a form of psychotherapy in which one or more therapists treat
a small group of clients together as a group. The term can legitimately refer to
any form of psychotherapy when delivered in a group format, including Cognitive
behavioural therapy or Interpersonal therapy, but it is usually applied to
psychodynamic group therapy where the group context and group process is
explicitly utilised as a mechanism of change by developing, exploring and
examining interpersonal relationships within the group. The broader concept of
group [[therapy]] can be taken to include any helping process that takes place
in a group, including support groups, skills training groups (such as anger
management, mindfulness, relaxation training or social skills training), and psycho-
education groups. The differences between psychodynamic groups, activity groups,
support groups, problem-solving and psycoeducational groups are discussed by
Montgomery (2002). Montgomery C (2002) Role of dynamic group therapy in
psychiatry Advances in Psychiatric Treatment, 8(1): 34-41 Other, more
specialised forms of group therapy would include non-verbal expressive therapies
such as art therapy, dance therapy, or music therapy.
